unnormalised: **What are some effective training regimens for different sports, keeping in mind the Indian context?**
normalised: What are some effective training regimens for different sports, keeping in mind the Indian context?

unnormalised: Okay, so you want to level up your game, eh? Training regimens are super important, and what works for Virat Kohli might not work for Rohan. It all depends on your sport, your body, and your goals.
normalised: Okay, so you want to level up your game, eh? Training regimens are super important, and what works for Virat Kohli might not work for Rohan. It all depends on your sport, your body, and your goals.

unnormalised: For cricket, especially if you're aiming to be a bowler like Bumrah, a combination of strength training (think squats, deadlifts), endurance runs (5 km runs 3 times a week should do the trick), and of course, hours honing your bowling action at the nets. Remember, consistency is key. Practice at 16:00 hrs is as important as practice at 09:00 hrs.
normalised: For cricket, especially if you're aiming to be a bowler like Bumrah, a combination of strength training (think squats, deadlifts), endurance runs (five kilometer runs three times a week should do the trick), and of course, hours honing your bowling action at the nets. Remember, consistency is key. Practice at sixteen hundred hours is as important as practice at zero nine hundred hours.

unnormalised: For badminton, something like what Sindhu might do, agility drills are crucial. Think ladder drills, cone drills, and lots of footwork practice. Stamina is also a big deal, so interval training (sprints followed by rest) is your friend. Don't forget those all-important smashes!
normalised: For badminton, something like what Sindhu might do, agility drills are crucial. Think ladder drills, cone drills, and lots of footwork practice. Stamina is also a big deal, so interval training (sprints followed by rest) is your friend. Don't forget those all-important smashes!

unnormalised: If you're into running, maybe like the athletes from Army Sports Institute, Pune, then it’s all about building mileage gradually. Start with short runs and slowly increase the distance over time. Include tempo runs (sustained effort at a comfortably hard pace) and hill repeats to build strength. Hydration is *especially* crucial in the Indian heat. Also, adequate rest between runs is extremely important, remember the 2nd of October Gandhi Jayanti is a very good day to just rest.

unnormalised: Remember to listen to your body! If you're feeling pain, take a break. Consult a coach or a physiotherapist at a local sports center, maybe even the one at IIT Madras if you're in Chennai. They can help you create a regimen that’s tailored to your needs. And don't forget the importance of a good diet – lots of protein, vegetables, and remember, even a small serving of those delicious gulab jamuns on special occasions doesn’t hurt! Good luck, and train hard!
